docs.lead_paragraph: Awake, Jim Smith was an amiable and popular man. As the director of public works in the small town of Osseo, Minn., he could be counted on to make house calls day or night, attending to burst pipes or broken water mains.

headline.main: When the Brain Disrupts the Night

docs.abstract: Researchers probe REM behavior disorder and other so-called parasomnias that involve odd or dangerous behavior during sleep; Jim Smith has REM behavior disorder and, while asleep, will shout obscenities, kick walls, punch pillows, and sometimes hit his wife; researchers find that such disorders can be successfully treated, that most have nothing to do with mental illness and that some have surprising links to physical illness; research is challenging basic assumptions about sleep and wakefulness, showing that borders between two states are far from clearly demarcated; photos; diagram shows recording of 42 second of sleep activity in Smith (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES, in the crush of news, seemingly minor things that later prove significant are overlooked. That may have been the case last fall when Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana said he had changed his mind and was now calling for universal health care coverage because the American system of medical care ''is collapsing around us.''
